intro: Silene vulgaris f. rhiphaea, commonly known as the hairy stork's bill, is a flowering plant characterized by its distinctive, erect stems and small, pinkish-white flowers. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family and is native to parts of Europe and Asia. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and sandy soils. Its leaves are often covered in fine hairs, giving it a distinctive textured appearance. The fruit is a capsule that splits open to release seeds, contributing to its propagation in suitable environments.
